questions.question: Which action below shows a physical change to an object?

answers.content: Bending a pipe cleaner into a spiral
answers.explanation: Bending changes the shape but the pipe cleaner is still the same material.

answers.content: Burning a piece of paper into ash
answers.explanation: Burning is a chemical change, the paper turns into a new material (ash).

answers.content: Watching a balloon on a table
answers.explanation: No change happens.

answers.content: Adding food colouring to water to make coloured water
answers.explanation: The colour changes because a new substance is mixed in – not simply a physical change of the water alone.

questions.question: After you cut a sheet of paper into small shapes, what material are the pieces made of?

answers.explanation: Cutting only changes the size and shape; the material remains paper.

questions.question: Name one object you changed in Activity 4 and describe how its shape looked afterwards.

answers.content: I squashed an empty aluminium can so it looked flat.

questions.question: When the child blew air into the balloon, which property of the balloon changed the MOST?

answers.explanation: The balloon became larger and rounder while still made of rubber.

questions.question: Draw (1) what one of your objects looked like BEFORE you changed it and (2) what it looked like AFTER. Label the object’s material and write the action you used (e.g., twisting, folding).

answers.content: Teacher rubric: 1 mark for clear before drawing; 1 mark for clear after drawing; 1 mark for correct labelling of material and action.

questions.question: Which action below is an example of stretching a material?

answers.content: Pulling the ends of a rubber band farther apart.
answers.explanation: Stretching involves pulling a material to make it longer.

answers.content: Twisting the lid off a bottle.
Bending a plastic straw into a curve.
Rolling a ball of modelling clay.

questions.question: Which material is MOST likely to bend without breaking?

answers.explanation: Rubber is flexible and elastic, so it can bend without snapping.

questions.question: Explain why aluminium foil can be twisted into a tight ball, but a plastic cup usually cannot be twisted. Write one or two sentences.

answers.content: Aluminium foil is thin and flexible so it can twist easily, while a plastic cup is rigid and holds its shape, so twisting would crack or crease it instead of smoothly changing its form.

questions.question: Choose an object you can see in the classroom. 1. Draw the object. 2. Label the material it is made from. 3. Use arrows and words to show ONE action (bend, stretch, or twist) that could physically change its shape.

answers.content: Student includes a clear drawing, a correct material label (e.g., “rubber”, “metal”, “plastic”), and shows an appropriate action with arrows and words (e.g., arrows pulling on a rubber band labelled “stretch”).

questions.question: Select ALL actions that are examples of reversible physical changes.

answers.content: Bending a pipe cleaner into a circle

questions.question: What usually happens to ice when heat is added to it?

answers.content: It melts and becomes liquid water.
answers.explanation: Heating gives the ice energy, breaking the bonds that keep the water particles in a solid arrangement.
Freezing happens when heat is removed, not added.

answers.content: It turns straight into steam without melting first.
answers.explanation: Ice normally melts to liquid water before it can evaporate at normal classroom temperatures.
A temperature rise will always cause some change in the ice.

questions.question: When fruit is placed in a freezer, which change can you best observe?

answers.content: It becomes harder and its juice turns to ice.
answers.explanation: Water inside the fruit freezes, making the fruit feel hard and icy.
Boiling requires heating, not cooling.
Freezing does not usually remove colour.
Drying is caused by evaporation, a warming process.

questions.question: Give two of the five senses you were asked to use during the Frozen Fruit Investigation.

answers.content: Any two of: sight/seeing, touch/feeling, smell, taste, hearing/sound
answers.explanation: Students used their senses to describe changes to the fruit.

questions.question: What is the correct scientific term for warming frozen fruit until it becomes soft again?

answers.explanation: Thawing means changing from frozen (solid) to unfrozen (usually liquid/soft) as heat is added.
Freezing is cooling a liquid until it turns solid.
Evaporation changes liquid to gas, not frozen fruit to soft fruit.
Condensation is gas turning into liquid.

questions.question: Draw and label a piece of chocolate before it is heated and after it has warmed up in the sun.

answers.content: Teacher-graded drawing showing: BEFORE – solid, keeps shape. AFTER – partially or fully melted, loses shape/drips.
answers.explanation: The drawing should clearly show that heating causes the chocolate to melt and change shape.

questions.question: Why were you asked to wash your hands before handling the fruit in the investigation?

answers.content: To prevent germs from getting on the food and keep everyone safe.
answers.explanation: Clean hands reduce the spread of germs when working with food during science activities.

answers.content: Because warm water makes the fruit thaw faster.
answers.explanation: Hand-washing temperature does not affect how quickly the fruit thaws on the plate.

answers.content: So the teacher can see who is paying attention.
answers.explanation: The main reason is hygiene, not discipline.

answers.content: Hand washing changes the taste of the fruit.
answers.explanation: Hand washing does not change the flavour of the fruit itself.
